job_title: Behavior Therapist in Fairfield, CA
pros:
Great opportunity to change a child's life
Great learning experience
Good flexibility with hours
Great team
cons: They tell you that you need 30 hours for benefits whenever the scheduler is not even allowed to schedule any more than 28. I gave up a semester of school, and a really good job opportunity for Easter Seals because I thought I was doing the right thing. I don't really have the support and the training once you get to your home office is very poor. Like I spent the first week and half just completely lost because I didn't know what I was supposed to be doing, and I had no real direction as to which direction to go. The hours are very poor, like my schedule is embarrassing hours a week.

review_title: Innovative nonprofit that is pioneering in technology and the delivery of services to the disabled
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pleasant Hill, CA
pros: Easter Seals Bay Area is a pioneer in leveraging technology to serve the disabled.  The combination of a trusted established nonprofit with the proximity to leading Bay area technology companies makes this one of the most interesting nonprofits in Northern Califronia.  They are attracting an A-team of technical and leadership talent.; they are investing in great technology solutions.  For those tired of the all-consuming hours and lack of diversity and mission in many of the major technology companies, Easter Seals Bay Area provides a welcome alternative.  Great life balance and integrity.
cons: Company has been growing so rapidly that there are many opportunities for growth and advancement,  but sometimes the internal processes are being stretched to capacity.  For those who have worked in an entrepreneurial fast-moving culture -- but who would like to work for a mission-based organization --  there are many opportunities to create solutions and provide leadership.

job_title: Case Manager in Hayward, CA
pros: Conveinance, technologically savvy, and decent benefits.
cons:
I worked at this company full-time and let me tell you, if it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck then it’s definitely not a goose - there’s a reason why this company has such awful reviews and it’s not by chance.

The leadership there can and will throw anyone under the bus to serve their own self-interests and the lack of training at this company was pathetic. People get hired there and don’t get any training or support but then get reprimanded for not knowing how to do the things they weren’t shown how to do. When a company’s leadership only values $ and not the people who work their tails off for them, it creates a toxic and conflictial environment.

 From the top down, the leadership uses deception to present its best face. 

Want an example? Read the lone positive review from the individual claiming to be a current employee who worked as a case manager for 5 years. Too bad that program didn’t exist 5 years ago, weird how that happens to be the only great review right?

job_title: in Pleasant Hill, CA
pros: The people who work there are great; they care about their clients and strive to be the leader in how services are provided. The organization is in a huge growth phase and there are lots of opportunities for growth and expansion of knowledge that I did not find at previous nonprofits. Leadership is engaged in moving the agency forward in a sustainable but innovative way. Managers will find resources when needed to support employees.
cons: Sometime there is too much work to do on a day to day basis and not enough time to get it all done- typical of a nonprofit. Communications are sometimes difficult because of the different locations and remote employees. Turnover is huge because of the fast growth.

job_title: Behavior Therapist in San Jose, CA
pros: Enthusiastic and supportive staff-1 star.
cons:
A LOT OF PROBLEMS IN THIS COMPANY!!!
- After being here a year, I referred in a friend of mine, and they paid him MORE
- Supervisors REFUSE to enter data and make the therapists do it, and would rather cut into therapy time with clients than enter in data.
- as of this date, 9/25/16, they had JUST rolled out a new "policy" that literally cut every one's pay by 1/3.
- After numerous complaints from fellow co workers and families of clients I had, I applied to their HQ to help with HR services. The head of HR interviewing me did not even know that there was more than ONE therapist per client.
- At a company where employee retention is extremely low, slowing progress and inhibiting client development, HQ decided to go with some one more "experienced" rather than promote from within, and maintain positive employee retention

review_title: The other reviews are SPOT ON!!!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Competitive Pay. Salaried Position. Benefits. Career advancement IF you don't question management.
cons:
Whew!!! Where do I begin? For starters, the review entitled "Toxic Environment" completely mirrors my experience. Many colleagues are unfriendly and management is UNAVAILABLE. 

As a Case Manager, my role keeps me glued to my computer. I feel more like a salesperson than a Masters trained clinician. The position is new and is being redefined on a day-to-day basis. What does this mean? Well, 1 year ago this position DID NOT exist, which is painfully obvious. A new ABA contract with Kaiser created this role and I must say, I wonder just how long this program will survive, and how much longer will "things change daily" be passed as a joke. 

Further, management is not invested in retaining CMs, at least those that are not favored. It is such shame that this position is so poorly designed. I would not recommend this position to anyone.

job_title: Behavior Interventionist in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Flexible office hours

- Supports internal growth/future education if you're planning to become BCBA certified to become a program supervisor/clinical manager

- Mileage reimbursement 

- Most program supervisors/clinical managers are really supportive of their BIs and are super dedicated to their work!

- Non-profit organization, has been around for over 90 years!  

- Rewarding work
cons:
- Huge turnover rate 
- Pay is not competitive and work can be very exhausting 
- Client cancellations/Scheduling is difficult sometimes because of the inconsistency, especially when you're working with a client and their family's schedules
- Majority of work is from 2-7PM (because most clients are in school), can be a pro or a con
- BIs are expected to be on-call for substitute sessions if their clients cancel but are not paid to be on-call 
- 70% direct hours, 30% indirect office hours - sometimes, doesn't seem like it is enough hours to properly session plan/input data/prepare for future sessions

job_title: Clinical Case Manager in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: The environment is very positive, good benefits, and supportive supervisors.  The  team members are very supportive to each other.  You can have a  flexible schedule as long as you document your time, let your boss know and put in  your 40 hours a week. Also, the new location of the office is really nice with a cafe and gym onsite.
cons: Things change fast so be ready for changes. Also you have to be very knowledgeable about various computer programs and get comfortable with  it fast. It is a high tech clinical environment which is not the norm for traditional clinical protocols.  Overall I like it, but it’s not for everyone.

job_title: Behavior Therapist in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Clinical Staff is very supportive.
cons:
The company hires only as part-time, but it gives you the illusion that when you fill up your schedule and you reach the 35 hours a week can become a full-time employee. The reality is that they do not let you fill up your schedule, even if there are clients in the waiting list. What they do is keeping your schedule 1 or 2 hours away from the 35 hours a week. 
Another problem with Easterseals is sessions cancellation .  Because the company does not place any rules for families for session cancellation, is very common that behavior technicians drive to session location, find out that session has been canceled, and go back home without compensation for mileage and hours. It happens very often, and it can cost you a lot of money.

job_title: Manager in Pleasant Hill, CA
pros: Great mid and low level staff engagement a program and team work, we all work for the mission and goals of the children and those in the community with disabilities, amazing childrens program and the direct care staff are amazingly dedicated .  The reason the organization exists is crucial and the services change lives for the good.
cons: The senior leadership lost site of the mission, and do not seem to put staff in the position of authority and trust.  They often lose quality staff, their priorities are really not the industry of care, they are after money, continuously giving the top four raises while leaving the remaining staff out.  They

job_title: Client Placement in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Helping Clients and Staff get all their hours and have progress with their lives and well being. Ability to relieve families of stressful situations to show their children how to adapt to their environment
cons: Poor Management, lack of follow through  upper management when reporting issues within department . Not firing poor staff who make continuous mistakes and bring department down. Not listening to staff when pointing out with documentation a frequented incident that keeps happening and not training the offender to stop making same mistakes. Promoting unqualified and not well experienced people to lead roles over seasoned employees.

job_title: Behavioral Interventionist in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexible hours, can take unpaid time off. We get two floating holidays per year. Not many other pros.
cons: This company does not care for their employees too well. Employees are evaluated every 6 months to see if they get to keep their benefits or lose them (based on how many hours you have been averaging a week). Hours are pretty hard to get, and they keep hiring too many people. People are dropping like flies. Pay is very bad in comparison to other companies in the area.

job_title: Behavioral Interventionist in San Jose, CA
pros: The best part about working with ESBA is that you get to work with children and their families. Being a part of their growth and development is so rewarding.
cons:
Unfortunately, sometimes, there is not much growth. 

Some supervisors don't have time to respond or support you, but you are still expected to implement a behavioral plan that you didn't develop and don't have much knowledge about. On cases that might be very challenging, you find yourself struggling for the full two-hours of session, no matter how much experience you have. Despite reaching out to the supervisor, you are not given any support whatsoever. There are little collaboration opportunities between team members, which makes no sense to me. How can you effectively support a client when each of you are on your own? What is the point of a team, then?

I am not surprised at the high-turnover rate. It is such a disservice to the clients: in those two hours, multiple times a week, they could be learning and growing, but instead,  stagnancy and waste of time that is precious to their critical developmental periods.  It is so sad. Constantly having new BI's, PS's, and CM's does not help at all.

BI's are the direct line of service. They should be valued and supported when having to implement these behavioral plans, that they did not create, without a BCBA/behavioral analysis background. ESBA does not ensure that the plans are being carried out effectively, if at all (How can you run goals when the clients are constantly engaging in behaviors, and no one supports you in this?). Non-existent raises to the low wages earned and decreasing of drive-time/mileage reimbursement further conveys how much the BI's, I repeat: the direct line of service, are valued.

review_title: Good company for a very stressful job field
job_title: Behavioral Interventionist in Oakland, CA
pros:
Supportive management. 
Generous vacation and sick time, even for part time. 
Mileage reimbursement for most sessions, and drive time reimbursement between sessions.
Full-time benefits available for part-time workers (27+ weekly hours over 6 months).
cons:
Little interaction with other employees - inherent to home-based behavioral therapy. 
The office atmosphere affords few casual opportunities to blow off steam about frustrating moments with clients.
Often stressful work, with high turnover.
Frequent management pressure to take on more hours. 
Cumbersome, poorly managed annual performance evaluation period (5 months and counting!). 
Tedious paper trails for everything.

job_title: Behavior Interventionist in San Jose, CA
pros: One of the only ABA company's where you receive a phone/ computer for work. People are leaving a lot so currently you are able to get decent amount of hours, if you ever are so inclined. Kids are awesome! The office environment and culture is great.
cons: The turn over rate is high. Easter Seals is not the best paying ABA company. It's hard to get a raise. Clients cancel pretty often you only get paid if the family doesn't show up, or you get a sub session.

job_title: Clinical Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Has been a great place to work. A very collaborative clinical model and encouraging supervisors. I really appreciate how they're always looking to provide the best possible services to their clients.
cons: Working hours can be tough, but I think that's the nature of the work. Most clients are seen after school hours, which means you need to see clients in the evenings.

job_title: Behavioral Interventionist in San Jose, CA
pros: The kids and families are great, flexible schedule, it is fun to be able to play with kids toys again.
cons: The management is very corrupt. Supervisors harass their employees and do not even get a slap on the wrist when complaints are made through HR. The pay is REALLY bad compared to competing companies in the area. Everything is so disorganized that an employee can go months flying under the radar with no contact from a supervisor at all.

job_title: Behavioral Interventionist in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Laptops and cell phones
- Nice and friendly staff
- Professional
- Stepping stone
cons:
- No raises
- Bad communication with upper management, they can forget about you
- Driving takes a toll, they would make you drive 15+ miles and gives you 30 mins to get there during traffic hour
- High turn over rate

job_title: Case Manager in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Could have been great, but they lost sight of their purpose a long time ago. D
cons:
Everyone…I mean EVERYONE here is on edge! So much so, no one is allowed to even make suggestions or question practices! Even when their license could potentially be at risk! This toxic work environment that makes it completely impossible to get any work done when everyone is so stressed out and complains 24/7.

They tell you your caseload is around 200…..ya try 400-500.

So many grievances from families its ridiculous…be prepared to deal with that all day long.

Families aren’t even given an expected treatment time frame, because BI’s quit all the time. A typical ABA case can wait around for 6 months or more before treatment starts! So the parents will be calling you every day. Every BI review on glassdoor is 100% true.

Don’t push back or you’ll get fired.

If you want to keep up with your caseload, you’ll work 40 per week and bring work home…guaranteed.

They will try to low ball you with pay…don’t take less than 70k!

You’ll have minimal client interaction and will be sitting in front of a computer 24/7 processing grievances, processing reports, and taking a million complaints. Oh ya, you actually have 5 days to process reports once they hit your Sales Force Que.

Another thing….they just launched Sales Force this past summer and their training on this platform is such a joke! You’ll sit in front of a pre-recorded training class, not even a professionally scripted one. Just something they slapped together during their cut over from JIRA. Then you’ll be told to referrer to the incorrect SOP’s and Job Aids! So hopefully you’re good at reading dry and very incomplete material and you have a figure it out attitude

Lastly….I question how long they will manage to keep their contract with Kaiser. 

Good Luck to anyone thinking about working here. I'm sure you will be posting your negative review shortly. Keep your resume UPDATED!

job_title: Case Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good hours, salaried, flexible, great families, great group of people to work with, great group of providers to work with, great opportunity to network, learn lots
cons: expected to work more than 40 hours per week. No raises are allowed, no working from home, upper management does not listen to ideas from employees, must do more that job expectations with no compensation.
